awd_abstract_narration:
The mathematician Stefan Banach defined a mathematical object that we now call a Banach space. The theory of Banach spaces extended certain work of Volterra and Hilbert, among others. Operators on Banach spaces form the mathematical models for many objects in physics and engineering. Banach space operator theory has a long history within mathematics itself and is connected to other areas of mathematics, including partial differential equations and algebraic topology. The focus of this project is on certain aspects of the theory of operators on Banach spaces that have relevance for physics, engineering, and various areas of mathematics. 

The main goal of this project is to extend useful results concerning operators on Hilbert spaces to the setting of Banach spaces. For instance, the extent to which results about extensions of C*-algebras hold for algebras of operators on Banach spaces is considered. Since many proofs about operators on Hilbert spaces do not directly generalize to operators on Banach spaces, it is expected that extending these results requires different approaches. Results from Banach space theory, especially the use of probabilistic techniques, are expected to be useful.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted to increase our understanding of operators on Banach spaces, which form the mathematical models for many objects in physics and engineering. The PI showed that a C*-algebra is isomorphic to a subalgebra of operators on a discrete l^p space with p strictly between 1 and infinity and not equal to 2, if and only if the C*-algebra is residually finite dimensional. The PI, A. Bandeira and R. van Handel found an easily computable quantity that measures noncommutativity of operators on finite dimensional Hilbert spaces so that a sufficient condition for strong asymptotic freeness of certain random matrices can be formulated using this quantity. This proves strong asymptotic freeness for a large class of random matrices with jointly Gaussian entries. This includes certain sparse Gaussian random matrices. In addition, we proved a matrix concentration inequality where the logarithmic factor in the matrix Bernstein inequality is removed and a second order term that involves the above mentioned quantity that measures noncommutativity is added as a trade off. This inequality is, up to a constant, sharp for Wigner matrices. The PI organized a reading seminar for graduate students on uses of probability in functional analysis and its related fields.
